mn87:1.1.comm: King Pasenadi had what seems to be his first conversation and conversion with the Buddha in SN 3.1. However, it would seem his faith was still weak, as he is frustrated by the devotion of his chief queen, Mallikā (“Jasmine”). Ultimately, her wise counsel persuades him. Similar conversations with Mallikā on attachment to loved ones are found at SN 3.8 and Ud 5.1. King Pasenadi’s committment to non-attachment was sorely tested with the birth of a daughter (SN 3.16), and when Mallikā passed away (AN 5.49).

mn87:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn87:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn87:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena aññatarassa gahapatissa ekaputtako piyo manāpo kālaṅkato hoti.
mn87:2.1.eng: Now at that time a certain householder’s dear and beloved only child passed away.

mn87:2.2.pli: Tassa kālaṅkiriyāya neva kammantā paṭibhanti na bhattaṃ paṭibhāti.
mn87:2.2.eng: After their death he didn’t feel like working or eating.
mn87:2.2.comm: An unusual use of paṭibhāti (“feel like”); commentary glosses ruccati.

mn87:2.3.eng: He would go to the cremation ground and wail,

mn87:2.4.eng: “Where are you, my only child? Where are you, my only child?”

mn87:3.1.pli: Atha kho so gahapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho taṃ gahapatiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
mn87:3.1.eng: Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

mn87:3.2.pli: “na kho te, gahapati, sake citte ṭhitassa indriyāni, atthi te indriyānaṃ aññathattan”ti.
mn87:3.2.eng: “Your faculties, householder, are those of one who is unstable in their own mind; there is a deterioration in your faculties.”

mn87:3.3.eng: “And how, sir, could there be no deterioration of my faculties?

mn87:3.4.pli: mayhañhi, bhante, ekaputto piyo manāpo kālaṅkato.
mn87:3.4.eng: For my dear and beloved only child has passed away.

mn87:3.5.pli: Tassa kālaṅkiriyāya neva kammantā paṭibhanti, na bhattaṃ paṭibhāti.
mn87:3.5.eng: Since their death I haven’t felt like working or eating.

mn87:3.6.eng: I go to the cremation ground and wail:

mn87:3.7.eng: ‘Where are you, my only child? Where are you, my only child?’”

mn87:3.8.eng: “That’s so true, householder! That’s so true, householder!

mn87:3.9.eng: For our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.”

mn87:3.10.eng: “Sir, who on earth could ever think such a thing!

mn87:3.12.pli: Piyajātikā hi kho, bhante, ānandasomanassā piyappabhavikā”ti.
mn87:3.12.eng: For our loved ones are a source of joy and happiness.”

mn87:3.13.pli: Atha kho so gahapati bhagavato bhāsitaṃ anabhinanditvā paṭikkositvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
mn87:3.13.eng: Disagreeing with the Buddha’s statement, rejecting it, he got up from his seat and left.

mn87:4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sambahulā akkhadhuttā bhagavato avidūre akkhehi dibbanti.
mn87:4.1.eng: Now at that time several gamblers were playing dice not far from the Buddha.

mn87:4.2.pli: Atha kho so gahapati yena te akkhadhuttā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā akkhadhutte etadavoca:
mn87:4.2.eng: That householder approached them and told them what had happened.

mn87:4.3.pli: “idhāhaṃ, bhonto, yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho maṃ, bhonto, samaṇo gotamo etadavoca:

mn87:4.4.pli: ‘na kho te, gahapati, sake citte ṭhitassa indriyāni, atthi te indriyānaṃ aññathattan’ti.

mn87:4.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhonto, samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ etadavocaṃ:

mn87:4.7.pli: mayhañhi, bhante, ekaputtako piyo manāpo kālaṅkato.

mn87:4.8.pli: Tassa kālaṅkiriyāya neva kammantā paṭibhanti, na bhattaṃ paṭibhāti.

mn87:4.15.pli: Piyajātikā hi kho, bhante, ānandasomanassā piyappabhavikā’ti.

mn87:4.16.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, bhonto, samaṇassa gotamassa bhāsitaṃ anabhinanditvā paṭikkositvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamin”ti.

mn87:4.17.eng: “That’s so true, householder! That’s so true, householder!

mn87:4.18.eng: For our loved ones are a source of joy and happiness.”

mn87:4.19.pli: Atha kho so gahapati “sameti me akkhadhuttehī”ti pakkāmi.
mn87:4.19.eng: Thinking, “The gamblers and I are in agreement,” the householder left.

mn87:5.1.pli: Atha kho idaṃ kathāvatthu anupubbena rājantepuraṃ pāvisi.
mn87:5.1.eng: Eventually that topic of discussion reached the royal compound.
mn87:5.1.comm: Also a scene for gossip in AN 3.60 and AN 10.45.

mn87:5.2.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo mallikaṃ deviṃ āmantesi:
mn87:5.2.eng: Then King Pasenadi addressed Queen Mallikā,
mn87:5.2.comm: In addition to the conversations on the theme of attachment to loved ones, unrelated incidents with Mallikā appear at AN 4.197, Bu Pc 53:1.1, and Bu Pc 83:1.2.7. She is listed as an eminent lay disciple (AN 8.91–117:1.1) and maintained a monastery for philosophical debates (MN 78:1.3). This is what we know of her from early texts, while later Jātakas and other scriptures tell many colorful tales about her and her unique marriage. | Śvetāmbara Jains hold that, in the far distant past, the nineteenth founding teacher (tīrthaṅkara) was the lady Malli (Triṣaṣṭiśalākāpuruṣacaritra 6.6). Perhaps the Buddhist stories of the wise lady Mallikā helped inspire this legend.

mn87:5.4.eng: ‘Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.’”

mn87:5.5.eng: “If that’s what the Buddha said, great king, then that’s how it is.”

mn87:5.6.pli: “Evameva panāyaṃ mallikā yaññadeva samaṇo gotamo bhāsati taṃ tadevassa abbhanumodati:
mn87:5.6.eng: “No matter what the ascetic Gotama says, Mallikā agrees with him:

mn87:5.7.eng: ‘If that’s what the Buddha said, great king, then that’s how it is.’

mn87:5.8.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma, yaññadeva ācariyo antevāsissa bhāsati taṃ tadevassa antevāsī abbhanumodati:
mn87:5.8.eng: You’re just like a pupil who agrees with everything their tutor says.

mn87:5.10.pli: Evameva kho tvaṃ, mallike, yaññadeva samaṇo gotamo bhāsati taṃ tadevassa abbhanumodasi:

mn87:5.12.eng: Go away, Mallikā, get out of here!”

mn87:6.1.pli: Atha kho mallikā devī nāḷijaṅghaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ āmantesi:
mn87:6.1.eng: Then Queen Mallikā addressed the brahmin Nāḷijaṅgha,

mn87:6.2.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena bhagavato pāde sirasā vandāhi, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ puccha:
mn87:6.2.eng: “Please, brahmin, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

mn87:6.3.pli: ‘mallikā, bhante, devī bhagavato pāde sirasā vandati, appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchatī’ti;

mn87:6.5.pli: ‘bhāsitā nu kho, bhante, bhagavatā esā vācā—
mn87:6.5.eng: ‘Sir, did the Buddha make this statement:

mn87:6.6.eng: “Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress”?’

mn87:6.7.pli: Yathā te bhagavā byākaroti taṃ sādhukaṃ uggahetvā mama āroceyyāsi.
mn87:6.7.eng: Remember well how the Buddha answers and tell it to me.

mn87:6.8.eng: For Realized Ones say nothing that is not so.”

mn87:6.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhotī”ti kho nāḷijaṅgho brāhmaṇo mallikāya deviyā paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
mn87:6.9.eng: “Yes, ma’am,” he replied. He went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

mn87:6.10.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho nāḷijaṅgho brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn87:6.10.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

mn87:6.11.pli: “mallikā, bho gotama, devī bhoto gotamassa pāde sirasā vandati; appābādhaṃ appātaṅkaṃ lahuṭṭhānaṃ balaṃ phāsuvihāraṃ pucchati;
mn87:6.11.eng: “Worthy Gotama, Queen Mallikā bows with her head to your feet. She asks if you are healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.

mn87:6.13.pli: ‘bhāsitā nu kho, bhante, bhagavatā esā vācā—

mn87:6.14.eng: ‘Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.’”

mn87:7.2.eng: For our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

mn87:8.1.pli: Tadamināpetaṃ, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā piyajātikā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā piyappabhavikā.
mn87:8.1.eng: And here’s a way to understand how our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

mn87:8.2.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa, imissāyeva sāvatthiyā aññatarissā itthiyā mātā kālamakāsi.
mn87:8.2.eng: Once upon a time right here in Sāvatthī a certain woman’s mother passed away.

mn87:8.3.pli: Sā tassā kālakiriyāya ummattikā khittacittā rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāha:
mn87:8.3.eng: And because of that she went mad and lost her mind. She went from street to street and from square to square saying,

mn87:8.4.pli: ‘api me mātaraṃ addassatha, api me mātaraṃ addassathā’ti?
mn87:8.4.eng: ‘Has anyone seen my mother? Has anyone seen my mother?’

mn87:9-14.1.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā piyajātikā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā piyappabhavikāti.
mn87:9-14.1.eng: And here’s another way to understand how our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

mn87:9-14.2.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa, imissāyeva sāvatthiyā aññatarissā itthiyā pitā kālamakāsi …
mn87:9-14.2.eng: Once upon a time right here in Sāvatthī a certain woman’s father …

mn87:9-14.8.pli: Sā tassa kālakiriyāya ummattikā khittacittā rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāha:
mn87:9-14.8.eng: And because of that she went mad and lost her mind. She went from street to street and from square to square saying,

mn87:9-14.9.pli: ‘api me sāmikaṃ addassatha, api me sāmikaṃ addassathā’ti?
mn87:9-14.9.eng: ‘Has anyone seen my husband? Has anyone seen my husband?’

mn87:15-21.1.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā piyajātikā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā piyappabhavikāti.
mn87:15-21.1.eng: And here’s another way to understand how our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

mn87:15-21.2.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa, imissāyeva sāvatthiyā aññatarassa purisassa mātā kālamakāsi.
mn87:15-21.2.eng: Once upon a time right here in Sāvatthī a certain man’s mother …

mn87:15-21.3.pli: So tassā kālakiriyāya ummattako khittacitto rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāha:

mn87:15-21.4.pli: ‘api me mātaraṃ addassatha, api me mātaraṃ addassathā’ti?

mn87:15-21.5.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā piyajātikā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā piyappabhavikāti.

mn87:15-21.6.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa, imissāyeva sāvatthiyā aññatarassa purisassa pitā kālamakāsi …

mn87:15-21.12.pli: So tassā kālakiriyāya ummattako khittacitto rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evamāha:
mn87:15-21.12.eng: And because of that he went mad and lost his mind. He went from street to street and from square to square saying,

mn87:15-21.13.pli: ‘api me pajāpatiṃ addassatha, api me pajāpatiṃ addassathā’ti?
mn87:15-21.13.eng: ‘Has anyone seen my wife? Has anyone seen my wife?’

mn87:15-21.14.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā piyajātikā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā piyappabhavikāti.
mn87:15-21.14.eng: And here’s another way to understand how our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.

mn87:22.1.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, brāhmaṇa, imissāyeva sāvatthiyā aññatarā itthī ñātikulaṃ agamāsi.
mn87:22.1.eng: Once upon a time right here in Sāvatthī a certain woman went to live with her relative’s family.

mn87:22.2.pli: Tassā te ñātakā sāmikaṃ acchinditvā aññassa dātukāmā.
mn87:22.2.eng: But her relatives wanted to divorce her from her husband and give her to another,

mn87:22.4.pli: Atha kho sā itthī sāmikaṃ etadavoca:
mn87:22.4.eng: So she told her husband about this.

mn87:22.5.pli: ‘ime, maṃ, ayyaputta, ñātakā tvaṃ acchinditvā aññassa dātukāmā.

mn87:22.7.pli: Atha kho so puriso taṃ itthiṃ dvidhā chetvā attānaṃ upphālesi:
mn87:22.7.eng: But he cut her in two and disemboweled himself, thinking,

mn87:22.9.pli: Imināpi kho etaṃ, brāhmaṇa, pariyāyena veditabbaṃ yathā piyajātikā sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā piyappabhavikā”ti.
mn87:22.9.eng: That’s another way to understand how our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.”

mn87:23.1.pli: Atha kho nāḷijaṅgho brāhmaṇo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena mallikā devī tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā yāvatako ahosi bhagavatā saddhiṃ kathāsallāpo taṃ sabbaṃ mallikāya deviyā ārocesi. Atha kho mallikā devī yena rājā pasenadi kosalo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ etadavoca:
mn87:23.1.eng: Then Nāḷijaṅgha the brahmin, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat, went to Queen Mallikā, and told her of all they had discussed. Then Queen Mallikā approached King Pasenadi and said to him,

mn87:24.2.comm: She was probably the daughter born to Pasenadi and Mallikā in SN 3.16.

mn87:24.5.pli: vajiriyā te kumāriyā vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
mn87:24.5.eng: If she were to decay and perish, would sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise in you?”

mn87:24.6.pli: “Vajiriyā me, mallike, kumāriyā vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṃ, kiṃ pana me na uppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
mn87:24.6.eng: “If she were to decay and perish, my life would fall apart. How could sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress not arise in me?”

mn87:24.7.pli: “Idaṃ kho taṃ, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn87:24.7.eng: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:

mn87:24.8.eng: ‘Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.’

mn87:25.1.eng: What do you think, great king?

mn87:25.4.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, vāsabhāya te khattiyāya vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?

mn87:25.5.pli: “Vāsabhāya me, mallike, khattiyāya vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṃ, kiṃ pana me na uppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?

mn87:25.6.pli: “Idaṃ kho taṃ, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:

mn87:26.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, piyo te viṭaṭūbho senāpatī”ti?
mn87:26.1.eng: Do you love your son, General Viḍūḍabha? …

mn87:26.3.pli: “Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, viṭaṭūbhassa te senāpatissa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjeyyuṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?

mn87:26.4.pli: “Viṭaṭūbhassa me, mallike, senāpatissa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṃ, kiṃ pana me na uppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?

mn87:26.5.pli: “Idaṃ kho taṃ, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:

mn87:27.1.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññasi, mahārāja, piyā te ahan”ti?

mn87:27.4.eng: If I were to decay and perish, would sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise in you?”

mn87:27.5.pli: “Tuyhañhi me, mallike, vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṃ, kiṃ pana me na uppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
mn87:27.5.eng: “If you were to decay and perish, my life would fall apart. How could sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress not arise in me?”

mn87:27.6.pli: “Idaṃ kho taṃ, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn87:27.6.eng: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:

mn87:27.7.eng: ‘Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.’

mn87:28.1.eng: What do you think, great king?

mn87:28.2.eng: Do you love the realms of Kāsi and Kosala?”
mn87:28.2.comm: Kosala is the native realm of Pasenadi. Kāsi had formerly been an independent kingdom, but was taken over by Pasenadi’s father Mahākosala. Towards the end of the Buddha’s life it was contested between Kosala and Magadha (SN 3.14, SN 3.15). Ultimately it became part of the greater Magadhan empire.

mn87:28.4.pli: Kāsikosalānaṃ, mallike, ānubhāvena kāsikacandanaṃ paccanubhoma, mālāgandhavilepanaṃ dhāremā”ti.
mn87:28.4.eng: It’s due to the bounty of Kāsi and Kosala that we use sandalwood imported from Kāsi and wear garlands, fragrance, and makeup.”

mn87:28.6.eng: If these realms were to decay and perish, would sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress arise in you?”

mn87:28.7.pli: “Kāsikosalānañhi, mallike, vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā jīvitassapi siyā aññathattaṃ, kiṃ pana me na uppajjissanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
mn87:28.7.eng: “If they were to decay and perish, my life would fall apart. How could sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress not arise in me?”

mn87:28.8.pli: “Idaṃ kho taṃ, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn87:28.8.eng: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:

mn87:28.9.eng: ‘Our loved ones are a source of sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.’”

mn87:29.2.pli: Yāvañca so bhagavā paññāya ativijjha maññe passati.
mn87:29.2.eng: how far the Buddha sees with penetrating wisdom, it seems to me.

mn87:29.3.comm: I think the king held his hands over a bowl and Mallikā poured water over them.

mn87:29.4.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā tikkhattuṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
mn87:29.4.eng: Then King Pasenadi got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:

mn87:29.5.eng: “Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

mn87:29.6.eng: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!

mn87:29.7.eng: Homage to him, the blessed one, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!”
